funder.name: National Natural Science Foundation of China

abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content>barcodes were studied for 1,353 specimens representing 272 morphological species belonging to 149 genera and 55 families of Perciformes from the South China Sea (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SCS</jats:styled-content>). The average Kimura 2‐parameter (K2P) distances within species, genera and families were 0.31%, 8.71% and 14.52%, respectively. A neighbour‐joining (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">NJ</jats:styled-content>) tree, Bayesian inference (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BI</jats:styled-content>) and maximum‐likelihood (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">ML</jats:styled-content>) trees and Automatic Barcode Gap Discovery (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">ABGD</jats:styled-content>) revealed 260, 253 and 259 single‐species‐representing clusters, respectively. Barcoding gap analysis (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BGA</jats:styled-content>) demonstrated that barcode gaps were present for 178 of 187 species analysed with multiple specimens (95.2%), with the minimum interspecific distance to the nearest neighbour larger than the maximum intraspecific distance. A group of three<jats:italic>Thunnus</jats:italic>species (<jats:italic>T. albacares</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>T. obesus</jats:italic>and<jats:italic>T. tonggol)</jats:italic>, a pair of<jats:italic>Gerres</jats:italic>species (<jats:italic>G. oyena</jats:italic>and<jats:italic>G. japonicus</jats:italic>), a pair of<jats:italic>Istiblennius</jats:italic>species (<jats:italic>I. edentulous</jats:italic>and<jats:italic>I. lineatus</jats:italic>) and a pair of<jats:italic>Uranoscopus</jats:italic>species (<jats:italic>U. oligolepis</jats:italic>and<jats:italic>U. kaianus</jats:italic>) were observed with low interspecific distances and overlaps between intra‐ and interspecific genetic distances. Three species (<jats:italic>Apogon ellioti</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>Naucrates ductor</jats:italic>and<jats:italic>Psenopsis anomala</jats:italic>) showed deep intraspecific divergences and generated two lineages each, suggesting the possibility of cryptic species. Our results demonstrated that<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content>barcodes are highly reliable for delineating species of Perciformes in the<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SCS</jats:styled-content>. The<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content>barcode library established in this study will shed light on further research on the diversity of Perciformes in the<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SCS</jats:styled-content>.</jats:p>
title: Developing a<scp>DNA</scp>barcode library for perciform fishes in the South China Sea: Species identification, accuracy and cryptic diversity
